raw_text:
Labour's core support takes stock
 
 Tony Blair has told Labour supporters he's "back" and still hungry for the job of prime minister - but does that sum up the mood at the party's spring conference in Gateshead?
 
 "The electorate are keener on the government than some Labour Party members," is the dry assessment of Graham Lane, leader of the Labour group on Newham Council. The problem, according to Mr Lane, is not continuing divisions over Iraq, foundation hospitals or tuition fees, or even voter apathy, but Mr Blair himself. "I have a new slogan. Vote Blair, Get Brown. That's what I am telling people on the doorstep. Don't worry, he will be gone soon." His friend, Saxon Spence, leader of Devon county Labour group, lays the blame for any lack of campaigning zeal on one issue above all others. "You cannot underestimate the impact of the war in Iraq. We lost people from our local party who had some key roles."
 
 But the two friends were fired up by Gordon Brown's speech on Saturday, with its appeal to core Labour values on social justice, health and education.
 
 "There was real passion. I think we have all felt a little jaded, but it reminded us why we joined the party in the first place," said Mrs Spence. "If he hadn't have walked off the stage, they would still be clapping," added Mr Lane. But for every Brownite at the spring conference there was an equally ardent fan of Mr Blair. Stephen Douglas, 26, from Wales, said after the PM's speech on Sunday: "I think it was a bit of a turning point, given the roasting he has had on some issues. The guy still has it."
 
 Tony Martin, of Burnley, said: "He is the first leader who has won us two terms. This bloke has delivered for us." Malcolm Shipley, of Shipley, said it was "as if he is coming round to the right approach again". Katrina Bull, a prospective parliamentary candidate said Mr Blair had shown he could rouse the party's grassroots: "I think if every voter was able to spend time in a room with Tony, the way we have today, we will have no problem with turnout." She had just emerged from a Q&A session, in which Mr Blair - tieless and supremely at ease - answered questions posed via the party's website.
 
 A party of councillors from Nottingham agreed that there was nothing wrong with Mr Blair's leadership - and they were adamant that the campaigning strength of the party in their city was as strong as ever. Iraq, they insisted, would not be a factor for most voters. "The biggest problem we have got at the moment is that we keep getting all these polls saying we are going to run away with the election. "It might sound great, but it does create this sense of complacency among our own voters and I think that is the greater problem than Iraq," said Nottingham City Councillor Brian Parbutt. And even Mr Blair's most vocal critics seemed to agree on one thing - he is a master of the sort of glossy, high-profile campaigning that has become Labour's hallmark, epitomised by Friday's whistle-stop tour of marginal seats. A group of shop stewards from the Swan Hunter shipyard, who said they were facing redundancy, could barely suppress their anger at Mr Blair's failure to, as they saw it, shake off his Tory leanings and stand up for manufacturing in the North East.
 
 They were also scathing about the alleged benefits of showpiece projects such as conference venue Sage Centre, heralded by John Prescott and others this weekend as a symbol of Labour's success in urban regeneration.
 
 "It is no good having the Sage or Baltic if you haven't got the money for the entrance fee," said Terry Telford. But when asked about Mr Blair's bravura performance on Friday, the men agreed he was "brilliant". And they would all be out on the doorstep pushing the Labour message come election time. "If you are not fired up about the election, then what's the point? There is no complacency as far as I can see in the Labour Party. We are fired up. We are up for this election," said Richie Porterhouse. Mr Telford agreed, but added it was becoming increasingly difficult to think of an answer when people asked "What has Labour done for the North East?" "I have had doors slammed in my face," he said.
 
 Every activist I spoke to said they were proud of what they believed Labour had achieved in their local communities - the new hospitals and schools, the better life chances for young people. The problem they faced, they said, was converting this local feelgood factor into votes. But they could at least rely on one "secret weapon", as one activist put it - Tory leader Michael Howard.
llama3.2:1b:
Labour's core supporters are still enthusiastic about the party, despite some divisions and concerns over leadership. 

Graham Lane of Newham Council believes the electorate is more interested in the government than Labour Party members. 
Tony Blair is back on board for prime minister but has not addressed specific issues such as Iraq or tuition fees.

Saxon Spence's group leader feels that Gordon Brown's speech rallied the party and reminded them why they joined. 

However, there are also fans of Tony Blair who praised his leadership after Brown's speech.

Labour councillors from Nottingham agree that Iraq will not be a factor in their voting decisions.

Tony Blair is seen as effective at campaigning for Labour, even if he lacks some Tory leanings.

Councillors face pressure to persuade voters to support the party despite concerns over manufacturing and conference venue costs.
llama3.2:3b: Labour's core support remains divided over Tony Blair's leadership amid concerns about his legacy in the aftermath of Iraq. However, many party members and activists remain enthusiastic about Gordon Brown's appeal to core Labour values during his speech at the spring conference, with some even suggesting that Brown is now a more suitable leader than Blair. Despite divisions over Blair's tenure, the party's grassroots remains committed to campaigning, with many arguing that the party's grassroot organization will ultimately secure Labour's success in the next election.
gemma2:2b:
Tony Blair's return to politics is a source of both support and criticism within the Labour party.  While some believe his leadership is crucial for electoral success, others are concerned about internal divisions and the impact of the Iraq war on voter turnout. 

The conference saw contrasting perspectives with attendees expressing strong opinions on Mr. Blair's performance and its potential for future elections.  Some criticize Mr. Blair's past actions and policies while emphasizing his ability to energize party members.  On the other hand, some express a sense of complacency due to polling data suggesting an easy victory in upcoming elections. 

Despite these internal divisions, the conference underscored strong local initiatives implemented by Labour parties across various regions. The success of such projects is viewed as crucial for garnering votes during the election. The lack of clear answers on how these achievements translate into tangible benefits for voters in the face of questions about local issues remains a challenge.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas from the text:

1. Tony Blair has promised to be prime minister and is still hungry for this role.

2. The Labour party's spring conference in Gateshead attracted a mix of supporters.

3. Saxon Spence, a former Devon County Labour group leader, blamed divisions over Iraq, foundation hospitals, and tuition fees.

4. Gordon Brown's speech on Saturday had a more positive impact on the campaign, with strong support from both sides of the party.

5. Tony Blair was praised for his leadership qualities, including his ability to win back voters through high-profile campaigns and his style of campaigning that includes grandiose events like the New York City Olympics.

6. Notable supporters mentioned include Stephen Douglas, who said the PM's speech reminded him why he joined the Labour Party, and Katrina Bull from Nottingham City Councillor Brian Parbutt, who defended Blair for not giving up on manufacturing in the North East.

7. Notable opponents criticized the PM for his lack of support among local voters, while also pointing out that they were still winning some battles with Labour at the party's doorstep.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Labour's spring conference in Gateshead saw supporters rally around Prime Minister Tony Blair despite his controversial Iraq war and other divisions within the party. Campaigning was criticized for lacking enthusiasm, with many believing the war was a key factor in Labour's loss of voter support. However, Gordon Brown's speech sparked renewed passion among supporters, including young campaigners who had previously lost faith in the party. Councillors from Nottingham felt that Blair's leadership and strong grassroots campaigning were essential to their success, while some shop stewards criticized his lack of attention to manufacturing jobs and showed anger at his failure to shake off his Tory leanings. Despite these criticisms, Labour activists remained passionate about the party's achievements in improving local communities and young people's prospects.
qwen2.5:3b:
Labour's core support takes stock

Tony Blair reasserts his appeal to Labour members during the party's spring conference in Gateshead, with differing views from councillors and activists about the state of the party. Despite continued divisions over Iraq, foundation hospitals, or tuition fees, the election mood seems more favorable towards the government than opposition voices suggest. Blair’s campaign has regained some traction after a disappointing response to Gordon Brown's speech on core Labour values. Criticism of Blair persists but is less pronounced compared to pre-election fervor, especially regarding his perceived lack of support for manufacturing in the North East and criticisms of showpiece projects like Sage Centre. Despite disagreements over specific issues, there’s unity around Blair’s ability to inspire grassroots engagement through high-profile campaigning. Activists emphasize local achievements such as new hospitals and schools, highlighting a need to translate this into electoral success.
opencoder:1.5b: The summary of the text is to provide a detailed analysis and discussion of Labour's support for its first general election in Northern Ireland. It summarizes the mood at the party's spring conference in Gateshead, discussing the voters' reactions towards Mr Blair's leadership and his campaigns, including issues like Iraq and social justice initiatives. The key takeaways include the support given by Tony Blair and his supporters who expressed their enthusiasm for the election.
smollm:1.7b:
The Labour Party has been in government since 1997 and has had a significant impact on the UK's social and economic policies. However, there are some criticisms that have been raised about the party's leadership and decision-making processes. Here are some of the key criticisms:

1. **Lack of transparency**: Some critics argue that Labour leaders are not transparent enough about their decision-making processes and policy choices. This lack of transparency can make it difficult for voters to understand the reasoning behind certain decisions.
2. **Influence peddling**: There have been allegations that some Labour leaders, particularly Jeremy Corbyn, have used their influence to promote their own interests rather than those of the party or its members. For example, Corbyn has been accused of using his position as leader to benefit his own family and business interests.
3. **Lack of accountability**: Some critics argue that Labour leaders are not held accountable for their actions in a timely manner. This can lead to a lack of trust in the party's leadership and decision-making processes.
4. **Corruption allegations**: There have been several high-profile corruption allegations against Labour leaders, including Corbyn, who has faced criticism over his handling of the 2017 general election campaign.
5. **Lack of diversity**: Some critics argue that Labour's leadership team is not diverse enough and does not reflect the makeup of the party or the UK as a whole. This lack of diversity can lead to a lack of representation for certain groups within the party.
6. **Influence over the media**: There have been allegations that some Labour leaders, particularly Corbyn, use their influence to shape the narrative around key issues and events. For example, Corbyn has been accused of using his position as leader to promote a particular view on Brexit.
7. **Lack of experience in government**: Some critics argue that Labour leaders are not experienced enough in government and do not have the necessary skills or knowledge to lead the party effectively.
8. **Disconnection from the party's base**: There have been allegations that some Labour leaders, particularly Corbyn, do not fully engage with the party's base and do not listen to their views on key issues. This can lead to a lack of trust in the party's leadership and decision-making processes.
9. **Lack of commitment to social justice**: Some critics argue that Labour leaders are not committed enough to social justice and human rights, particularly when it comes to issues such as poverty, inequality, and racial justice.
10. **Influence over the judiciary**: There have been allegations that some Labour leaders, particularly Corbyn, use their influence to shape the direction of the judiciary and promote certain cases or policies.

These criticisms are not necessarily universally accepted, and many voters and experts remain loyal to the Labour Party's leadership and decision-making processes. However, they do represent some of the key concerns that have been raised about the party's leadership and governance practices.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to create a concise summary of this text about Labour's leadership and party dynamics based on the provided passages. Let me read through each part carefully.

First paragraph: It talks about Tony Blair telling Labour supporters he is "back" but not sure if that captures the mood at their spring conference in Gateshead. The key points here are Blair's statement, the focus on Iraq issues, voter apathy, and Gordon Brown's speech.

Next section mentions Graham Lane of Labour Newham evaluating leadership based on votes for candidates like Tony Martin and Malcolm Shipley. They mention that Blair was the first to win two terms, which adds to their support. Also, there are statements by Spence about bias against Iraq, and others like Stephen Douglas. The speech was attended by both Blair supporters and Blair fans.

Then, Nottingham Councillor Brian Parbutt notes no issues with Blair's leadership, same as before, and that he's a good candidate for his city's campaigning. They mention the Sage Centre project's benefits but say it hasn't addressed Blair's issue.

Finally, there are sections about_Terrell Telford criticizing Sage Centre costs without money and others agreeing to vote based on message. Activists in Gateshead see local projects as their main gain, but they rely on Tory leader Michael Howard for support.

I need to condense this into a summary that includes the main ideas: Blair's statement at conference, voter apathy, Blair being the first to win two terms, the impact of Gordon Brown's speech, Nottingham Councillor Brian Parbutt, Tim Telford criticizing Sage Centre without money, and Michael Howard as the "secret weapon."

I should make sure each point is captured without getting into too much detail. Also, it's important to focus on key ideas like Blair being back at conference, voter issues, Blair's leadership influence, etc.
</think>

The Labour Party leader Tony Blair delivered a statement during their spring conference in Gateshead, claiming he was "back" and still hungry for power but not sure if that captures the mood. The party faced concerns about divisions over Iraq, apathy, and voters' lack of enthusiasm. Despite this, Blair was noted as the first to win two terms. Notable supporters included Tony Martin and Malcolm Shipley. Gordon Brown's speech on Saturday highlighted the impact of the Iraq war but faced criticism from Blair's allies. Nottingham Councillor Brian Parbutt noted no issues with Blair's leadership, aligning with their previous support for him. Tim Telford criticized a successful project without funds while others agreed to vote based on message. Activists in Gateshead praised local initiatives like new hospitals and schools but relied on Michael Howard as their "secret weapon."
tinyllama:1.1b: The Labour party's core support is still keen on the government and not hungering for another prime minister, according to polling conducted by the party's spring conference in Gateshead. The problem, according to Graham Lane of the Labour group on Newham Council, isn't the perceived failure of Tony Blair but rather his lack of campaigning zeal. The new slogan for a Labour Party resurgence is "Back our core support, get Brown" and a party of councillor representatives from Nottingham agree that Iraq and other poll concerns might have to be taken into account. Despite Mr Blair's popularity, his speech on Saturday was received well by attendees, with an ardent fan stating that "He is the first leader who has won us two terms." However, there are concerns that Mr Blair still needs to deliver for votes after he did not convince enough core Labour voters in the last election.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The main message from the text is that there seems to be a division among Labour supporters about whether Tony Blair is the best leader for the party or not. There are differing opinions, and many people seem to have mixed feelings about him. Some people believe he has done a good job, while others think he should step down. The text also mentions some key issues that are important to Labour supporters, such as social justice, healthcare, and education.
phi:2.7b:
Tony Blair has told Labour supporters he's "back" and still hungry for the job of prime minister - but does that sum up the mood at the party's spring conference in Gateshead? There are differing opinions among Labour Party members, with some blaming the divisions over Iraq, foundation hospitals, tuition fees, or even voter apathy on Mr Blair himself. However, there is general agreement that Gordon Brown' speech on Saturday sparked a re-energized enthusiasm for Labour. Supporters believe Mr Blair has delivered for them and is still passionate about their cause. 

Use Case 1: Conversation between two friends discussing the impact of Mr Blair's leadership on the party and its members.

Friend 1: Have you seen Tony Blair at the conference? He seems to be back and hungry for the job again.
Friend 2: Yeah, I saw him. It's interesting how he has managed to maintain his support among Labour Party members despite all the controversies.
Friend 1: True. Some people blame divisions within the party on Mr Blair himself, while others think it's because of voter apathy or issues like foundation hospitals and tuition fees.
Friend 2: I don't buy that. I believe Tony Blair is still hungry for power and sees Labour as his ticket to becoming Prime Minister once again.
Friend 1: But there are also those who say he hasn't delivered on some key promises, especially with the war in Iraq. It's a tough job trying to please everyone.
Friend 2: That's true. But I think the passion and enthusiasm he ignited during his speech on Saturday show that he still has the support of many members.
Friend 1: You're right. There was real excitement at the conference, and it reminded us all why we joined the party in the first place.
Friend 2: Exactly! Tony Blair has a way of rallying the grassroots, and I believe he can bring people together if given a chance.

Use Case 2: Debate between two colleagues on whether Mr Blair's leadership is causing complacency within the Labour Party.

Colleague 1: I'm starting to feel like there might be some complacency within the party because of Tony Blair's leadership. The polls keep saying we are going to win easily, and it creates a sense of complacency among our own voters.
Colleague 2: But isn't it a good thing that people believe in Labour so much? It shows that they trust Mr. Blair and his vision for the party.
Colleague 1: Trust is important, but if we don't engage with all voters and address their concerns, we risk losing their support altogether.
Colleague 2: I understand your point, but I think it's unfair to blame everything on Tony Blair. There are still issues like foundation hospitals and tuition fees that need attention.
Colleague 1: Of course, those issues exist. But if we can't even get our own voters excited about the upcoming election, how can we expect others to rally behind us?
Colleague 2: It's a tough balance to strike, but I believe Tony Blair is still doing his best to deliver for the party and its members. We just need to keep pushing him and remind ourselves of what Labour has achieved.

Exercise 1: What are some factors that may have influenced the mood at the Labour Party's spring conference in Gateshead?
Answer: The mood at the conference may have been influenced by divisions within the party over issues like the war in Iraq, foundation hospitals, tuition fees, or even voter apathy. There were also differing opinions on Tony Blair's leadership and his ability to deliver for the party and its members. Gordon Brown' speech on Saturday sparked enthusiasm among Labour Party members. Supporters believe Mr. Blair is still hungry for power and passionate about their cause.

Exercise 2: What are some arguments made by Labour Party members regarding Tony Blair's leadership?
Answer: Some Labour Party members blame divisions within the party on Mr. Blair himself, while others think it's due to voter apathy or other issues like foundation hospitals and tuition fees. However, there is general agreement that Gordon Brown' speech on Saturday re-energized the party and reignited enthusiasm for Labour. Supporters believe Tony Blair has delivered for them and remains passionate about their cause.
orca-mini:3b: Tony Blair has told Labour Party members he is "back" and still hungry for the job of prime minister, but the mood at the party's spring conference in Gateshead was not entirely sustained by his presence. Some activists expressed concern about the impact of the Iraq war on their local communities, while others praised the party's record on social justice, health and education. However, the core support for Labour appears to be keener on the government than some party members, according to Graham Lane, leader of the Labour group on Newham Council. Malcolm Shipley, a prospective parliamentary candidate, said Tony Blair had shown he could rouse the party's grassroots, while Katrina Bull, a candidate, disagreed with the perception that the party's campaigning strength was weak. However, some activists admitted they were struggling to convert their local feelgood factor into votes, and even those who praised Mr Blair's leadership acknowledged the need for a strong opposition to Tory leader Michael Howard.
hermes3:3b:
Labour conference mood summary: 
- Discontent with Blair's leadership, not due to policy issues but voter apathy and Blair himself.
- Passion from Brown's social justice speech in spring conference.
- Mixed reactions towards Blair's performance, with some supporters still loyal.
- Problems in converting local success into votes and winning over the electorate.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: At Labour party's spring conference in Gateshead, Tony Blair reassured supporters he is "back" and hungry for the role of prime minister, despite ongoing divisions within the party. Graham Lane, leader of the Labour group on Newham Council, believes that voter apathy rather than internal disagreements is causing problems for the party. However, Saxon Spence, leader of Devon county Labour group, attributes any lack of campaigning zeal to the impact of the Iraq war. Many attendees were fired up by Gordon Brown's speech emphasizing social justice, health, and education. Various Labour Party members expressed their support for Tony Blair and admiration for his previous leadership successes, though some critics acknowledged his past association with the Tories. While some party members believe that complacency may be harming their election chances, many remain committed to pushing the Labour message during upcoming elections.
chatgpt-4o-latest: At Labour's spring conference in Gateshead, party members expressed mixed feelings about Tony Blair's leadership. While some, like Graham Lane and Saxon Spence, were disillusioned, particularly due to the Iraq war, others remained supportive, citing his electoral success and campaigning skills. Gordon Brown's speech reignited enthusiasm among some members by emphasizing core Labour values. Despite concerns over complacency due to strong poll numbers, activists remained committed to campaigning. Some, like shipyard workers, criticized Blair for neglecting manufacturing, but even they acknowledged his political prowess. Labour supporters were proud of local achievements but struggled to translate them into national electoral support, though they saw Tory leader Michael Howard as a useful opponent.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour supporters are divided over who should be the next UK Prime Minister with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown receiving different messages from their supporters. The focus is not on divisions over issues such as Iraq, foundation hospitals or tuition fees but rather on Mr. Blair's leadership which some argue encourages voter confusion between him and Brown. Despite this, there was a significant passion in Gordon Brown's speech at the spring conference which appealed to core Labour values on social justice, health and education. The impact of the war in Iraq is being blamed for any lack of campaigning zeal, with key members from local parties losing valuable positions due to the conflict. However, the party's councillors from Nottingham insist that there is no issue with Mr. Blair's leadership and that the campaign strength remains strong in their city. Labour activists are facing challenges in converting their local achievements into votes; however, they can rely on Tory leader Michael Howard as a "secret weapon."

Graham Lane and Saxon Spence, council leaders, criticized Blair for dampening campaign enthusiasm due to the Iraq war and personal factors. However, Gordon Brown's speech on social justice, health, and education revived passion in many attendees. Stephen Douglas praised Blair for delivering two terms of success for Wales. Malcolm Shipley felt Blair was shifting towards a more conservative approach. Katrina Bull, a prospective candidate, believed Blair could energize the grassroots.

Nottingham City Councillor Brian Parbutt highlighted that while polls suggested strong potential for victory, this optimism might foster complacency among Labour voters. The group of shop stewards from Swan Hunter shipyard, facing redundancy, admitted Blair's performance was brilliant but expressed frustration with urban regeneration projects like the Sage Centre due to insufficient funding for local residents.

Across the party, activists were proud of Labour's achievements in their communities, such as new hospitals and schools. However, they struggled to convert this local feel-good into votes. A "secret weapon" was identified: Michael Howard, the Tory leader.
